topics.title: Directed Graph (Digraph)
content: Graph with edges having directions.
Example: A → B means from A to B only.

topics.title: Types of Digraphs
content: Simple Digraph – No loops, no multiple edges.
Multi Digraph – Multiple edges allowed.
Symmetric Digraph – A → B implies B → A.
Asymmetric Digraph – A → B exists, but not B → A.
Mixed Digraph – Contains both directed and undirected edges.

topics.title: Properties of Digraphs
content: In-degree = edges coming into vertex.
Out-degree = edges going out from vertex.
Total Degree = In-degree + Out-degree.
Sum of all in-degrees = sum of all out-degrees = number of edges.

topics.title: Digraphs and Binary Relations
content: Binary relation R on set A can be represented as digraph.
If (a,b) ∈ R, draw edge a → b.

topics.title: Directed Path
content: Sequence of vertices connected by edges, all in same direction.
Example: A → B → C

topics.title: Connectedness in Digraphs
content: Strongly Connected – Paths exist both ways between every pair.
Weakly Connected – Connected if directions ignored.
Unilaterally Connected – At least one of u → v or v → u exists.

topics.title: Euler Digraphs
content: Closed trail using every edge exactly once.
Conditions: In-degree = Out-degree for all vertices, and graph strongly connected.

topics.title: Directed Trees
content: Tree with directed edges.
Rooted with edges outward (arborescence) or inward (in-arborescence).
No cycles allowed.

topics.title: Fundamental Circuits in Digraphs
content: Closed directed path formed when a non-tree edge is added to spanning tree.
Each added edge creates one circuit.

topics.title: Adjacency Matrix of a Digraph
content: Square matrix showing vertex-to-vertex connections.
A[i][j] = 1 if edge i → j exists, else 0.
For weighted digraphs, entry = weight.
